nodes.bodyText: So the funnel table shows up when the forecast is selected, correct?
Yes, but only if the user clicks on the Metrics tab.  Do we want it to automatically select the Metrics table when the user selects forecast?

Will the upper and lower make separate calls to get the boundary values? I would prefer to make the boundary values be returned with the forecast values in one call because they are generated by the forecast provider together. I think it is quite expensive to run it 3 times.
Yes, the endpoint should grab all three values at once.  I wanted to send them to the frontend in this format to stay consistent with how the metric table currently receives its values.
The implementation is in this PR: #6432

This comparison is happening twice in this file; so it would be better to constantize forecast so any change to the string need to happen just once.
const FORECAST_MODE = 'forecast'

urn, isSelected, label, dataset, score, current, baseline, isExclusionWarning properties are same in both the if and else sections. Lets pull those out into a common object before the if..else and destructure that object in return in both if..else before proceeding to add unique properties in each.
I'm not sure about this approach, since we are iterating through keys and building rows based on the keys.  Wouldn't this be adding a lot of computational steps?
Actually yes, I misunderstood. I agree we should keep it they way it is.
It is better to add the type to avoid the type issue.

nodes.bodyText:
This seems like a map function.
const urlArr = externalUrls.map((urlLabel)=>{return [urlLabel]: attributes[urlLabel][0]})
it's better to add TODO and Jira Ticket to trace.
This is a prettify of old code.  I'm not sure what TODO would go here
If nothing is using this property, I'll go ahead and delete it.
The property gets passed down, so I believe it is being used.  It seems it was done to address a bug.  I'd better leave it.  fb3c74d

You can optimize the code.
if(_.isEmpty(e.selectedItems) || !onSelection) return
Why not give aggregates value of {} property level?
This is a prettify of older code that I didn't write.  Are you thinking it needs to be refactored?
we can refactor when we migrate code.
I'll leave this one for later consideration.  It seems good for now.
Why use two maps function here? One map could finish the result and will increase efficiency.
This is also not written by me but updated by prettify.  By looking at it, I believe "toAbsoluteUrn" is doing some work before the next map.
If you don't clear the logic, we can refactor when we do the migration.
I will condense it into one map.
